Kent,

I agree with your position, however I am at a new job and there is an 
existing body of tests that we would like to run within the JUnit 
framework. These tests lean more towards being functional tests and 
rely on multiple failures being handled correctly. There have been 
several opinions on this list in support of multiple failures for 
functional tests. 

What I would like to know is the reason TestCase inherits from Assert 
rather than delegates to it. If it delegated, we could subclass 
TestCase to handle multiple failures and still use Assert for DbC.

Regards,

David

--- In junit@y..., "kentlbeck" <kentbeck@c...> wrote:
> When I've wished for multiple failures to be recorded in my tests, 
my 
> tests were always too big. Splitting up the tests gave me more 
> satisfactory tests, and pinpointed errors.
> 
> If you want multiple failures, it sounds like you want a different 
> mechanism than fail().
> 
> The advantage of having the methods be static is that you can do 
DbC 
> and have pre-/post-condition failures reported like all other JUnit 
> failures.
> 
> Kent
